channel.title: A Frame/JFrame
channel.description: If you overwrite the painting methods inside of Frame or JFrame, you can paint custom things on the canvas (obvious). By doing this, you could, for instance, fill the background with a transparent color. The whole problem with this, if you repaint the Frame/JFrame, the color is stacked onto its old painting and renders the background more opaque. Does anyone have any idea to make the canvas of the Frame/JFrame like 'wipe away' its old painting?

item.title: A Frame/JFrame
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“lawl, post:3, topic:187078”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=249595.msg2095161#msg2095161 date=1204975904]
Transparency is fully possible. However, the only way you could do it well is if you could is repaint the JFrame the way the minimize button does. That minimize button somehow clears the canvas of the frame and updates the colors (which are 100% transparent). I was just asking if anyone knew how the minimize button worked (because I have been in and out of the JFrame and Frame sources and I cannot find anything about the minimize button.)
[/quote]
what are you talking about?[/quote]

I initialized a JFrame with its painting methods overwritten. Inside of them, I filled a rectangle to cover the entire canvas (white with about 30% transparency) and it worked. The problem was, if you move the frame you would see what ever was underneath it when it was first initialized. If you minimize the frame and maxmize it, it does the same thing- you can see through it to whatever is underneath it. So, I added a component listener to listen for when the frame was moved. Whenever it was moved I would repaint the frame. The problem with this was, if you fill a rect with partial transparency over a rectangle with the semi transparency then it will just become more opaque. Thus, the only way to ‘clear’ the canvas of the JFrame was to minimize and then maximize it again. Transparency is possible, its just you cannot make it constant.

Read full topic

item.title: A Frame/JFrame
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

Well then, I will happily wait for Java 7 to come out.

Read full topic

@frank wrote:

transparency is not supported in java currently, it is one of the features for java7, though

item.title: A Frame/JFrame
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

Transparency is fully possible. However, the only way you could do it well is if you could is repaint the JFrame the way the minimize button does. That minimize button somehow clears the canvas of the frame and updates the colors (which are 100% transparent). I was just asking if anyone knew how the minimize button worked (because I have been in and out of the JFrame and Frame sources and I cannot find anything about the minimize button.)

Read full topic

item.title: A Frame/JFrame
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

On another topic

the only thing you could do is take a screenshot and then draw it onto your jframe, but thats stupid and wont really work

Actually, that’s basically what even native apps do when compositing isn’t available.

For example:
Install linux+x, but no compositor. Get a terminal that supports transparency, such as XFCE Terminal. Turn transparency on. Drag the terminal so it obscures another window… and it fuckin’ explodes in a big fiery ball of death. Well no, it dosen’t but that’s where the shitty solution shows through.

Is this true, though? Does Java really not support transparency? Everyone keeps telling me how great the Java API/Stdlib/whatever is…

Read full topic

@frank wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:6, topic:187042”]Then you would just see the filled rectangle instead of what is behind the frame.[/quote]we dont know what you mean because you havent explained it, explain it or post a couple of screenshots?

item.title: A Frame/JFrame
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

Meh, I suppose no one here is understanding what I am trying to do. People said it is impossible to make a transparent frame in Java, but it really isn’t. The only problem I have is to clear the canvas of the frame without disposing it or turning off its visibility.

On another topic

graphics.clearRect(0, 0, getWidth(), getHeight())

That just sets the current Color of the graphics instance to the background of the frame and the fillRect()'s the specified area.

frank_:

draw a filled rectangle before you draw the rest on top of it

Then you would just see the filled rectangle instead of what is behind the frame.

Read full topic

item.title: A Frame/JFrame
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

draw a filled rectangle before you draw the rest on top of it

Read full topic

item.title: A Frame/JFrame
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

frank_:

paint a new image

I tried that. It does the same thing because it is painting a semi transparent image on top of another which makes the canvas more opaque. It seems the only way the canvas is wiped is when it is disposed or when it is minimized.

Read full topic
